title_narrative: Livelihood and Food Security Suragio del Norte 2018-2019 (YEP Ardjan)
description_narrative: The Netherlands Red Cross Under the Next Generation programme has prioritised youth development. Interventions for youth aim at developing youth as assets for agricultural and economic growth of the community and the country at large. A Young Expert will play a key role in addressing the development and food security/livelihoods needs of young people and their households. The Young Expert will contribute to enhancing the ability of the NLRC to save lives, protect livelihoods, promote sustainability and contribute to a healthier, safer and more resilient world. NRLC is seeking ways to increase our human resource capacity to ensure the effective delivery of programs. The Philippine Red Cross (PRC) currently does not have sufficient technical Food security and Livelihood. The Dutch Young Expert not only provides technical assistance to the project but also will  help to train the local  staff of the Philippine Red Cross and builds the project cycle management capacity of the PRC.

title_narrative: Eco-Smart Livelihoods and Food Security in Surigao del Norte
description_narrative:
The Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC) in partnership with Philippines Red Cross (PRC) and Local Government in Surigao Del Notre Province has launched a  3 year (2016-2018) integrated ‘Youth ignite: Agents of Change ’ project. The overall goal of the project is to enable youth cope with the impact and consequences of armed conflict and are thus adding to the overall resilience of the community.

This is the funding from YEP for the local Young Expert Earl Montero.

The project is targeting 5 municipalities affected by conflict and that are  also  affected by disasters such as floods, landslides, typhoons and earthquakes. These risks pose a huge threat to the lives of young people. The lack of employment opportunities and social safety nets generate tension and leave civilians with limited options for a sustainable livelihood. Within Surigao province, insufficient opportunities exist for young people to earn a living, subsequently heightening their chance of facing poverty and turning to illicit activities. Youth  face numerous serious struggles in their daily lives. They struggle with the threats of poverty, armed conflict and natural hazards that result in psychological and emotional distress and affects their perception of life. Increasing number of youths tends to focus more on surviving rather than prioritizing their education.

The Netherlands Red Cross recognize that conflicts and  disasters often require a commitment to longer-term recovery that extends beyond the provision of immediate food, shelter and medical assistance. Food security and eco-smart Livelihoods is a huge component of this project and seeks to help youth and their households recover or improve upon their pre and post-disaster living conditions in all areas and strengthen and sustain their livelihoods. The Food security and eco-smart Livelihood interventions will apply Sloping Agriculture Land Technology (SALT). SALT is a package technology used for soil conservation , crop production and diverse livelihoods options for farmers in mountainous/hilly areas. The main aspect of SALT farming is the use of contour bunds to conserve fertile topsoil and water. This ensures that farming on hillsides can be done in a more sustainable way. This approach to Food security and Livelihoods  will promote self-sufficiency among beneficiaries. Seeds can be harvested and stored for future use, bees are being kept to pollinate the plants, whilst at the same time providing honey, green cuttings can be fed to livestock that produces manure to in turn fertilize the soil. These aspects reduce the dependency of SALT farms on external inputs, such as expensive and potentially more damaging artificial fertilizers, and reduce the dependency of SALT farms on single products.

Using SALT approach, three (3) demonstration farms will be established in strategic locations-visible to community members for inspiration purposes. Two  livelihood training centres will be rehabilitated. 60 farmers will be organised to form 3 cooperatives , linked to the 3 demonstration farms. These livelihood centres will be used to provide eco-smart livelihood trainings for approximately 1200 youth in the project area.
Surigao Del Notre, Mindanao, Philippines
Support to Swiss RC on PER Assessment

The support provided is flexible and demand driven. It also follows a human centered process, ensuring that client needs and the local context drive the definition of NLRC's support. The identified needs must be realistic in scope, must be within the ability of the NLRC to answer and finally, there must be a clear commitment from the recipient NS to engage proactively with NLRC throughout the project. The countries that will ultimately receive support through this project have not yet been determined but are expected to primarily be in the MENA (Middle East and Northern Africa) regions. Based on the knowledge collected and the changing dynamic of the pandemic, we anticipate that recipient national societies will request data and digital support in the following (generic) areas:
1.	Continuation of crucial data & digital support for NS for emergency support products
2.	Support NS data and digital support for Covid vaccination campaign. 
3.	Compounding disasters:  disaster response complicated by to the Covid pandemic
4.	Cash IM support

Through the 510 Data & Digital Team NLRC assists 19 RCRC National Societies in their short-term preparedness and response to COVID-19 and supported their operational continuity, through data and digital. This support was made possible through a 12-month block funded project that started implementation on 1 April 2020. At the time of writing (2 months before the end of the project) several countries are encountering a renewed increase of infections. New uncertainties are introduced by the virus mutations, underlining that the Covid response phase is far from over. With the approval of several vaccines and the start of vaccination campaigns in countries around the world, the focus is beginning to shift from response to recovery. The road however remains long and based on the achievements of the 2020 global COVID program and the feedback received the added value of continued data and digital support beyond the current project's end date, 31 March 2021, is clear.

NLRC, through its 510 initiative provides remote technical assistance to RCRC national societies. IFRC will be involved to coordinate the support provided to countries in the MENA region and will itself also receive data & digital support from NLRC/510.

NLRC/510
IFRC MENA region
RCRC NS in the MENA region
MENA region

title_narrative: Improve patient administration systems in Palestinian hospitals in Lebanon
description_narrative: This programme aims to maintain and improve the quality of patient’s administration systems of hospitals that are run by the Palestine Red Crescent Society in Lebanon

The goal is to plan and implement demonstration of the concepts developed within S(P)EEDKITS. The project develops concepts for e.g. health care and sanitation solutions, infrastructural solutions, and shelter units.

The S(P)EEDKIT concept offers rapid humanitarian solutions – rapid deployment of shelters, facilities and medical care resources following major disasters - for self-recovery of communities. Currently, several developments have resulted in early field testing and deployment. The Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC), Médecins sans Frontières (MSF) and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), all partners within S(P)EEDKITS, have on-going field operations. Selected solutions can be tested in these humanitarian operations, usually in situations where infrastructure is poor and skilled labour scarce.

The focus will be on different levels of demonstration, focusing on key developments of S(P)EEDKITS at the different packaging levels (container, pallet, and bag), demonstration of rapid deployment, field testing of selected kits. The selected kits are shelter units, wash solutions (sanitation-, water -, and add-on kits), and infrastructural solutions. The aim is to demonstrate transportability and rapid deployment of the kits in an operational field context.

Partners in the S(p)eedkit project are: Médecins sans Frontières (MSF), The Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC), the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies Shelter Research Unit (IFRC-SRU) and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC).
Globally: the conditions for actual field deployment can vary rapidly.

The Humanitarian Innovation Coalition (HIC) provides an ecosystem for principled humanitarian innovation, by bundling strengths and combining efforts of committed public and private organizations in the Netherlands. Its primary goal is to contribute to increasing the impact of humanitarian service delivery to the vulnerable people most affected by a
humanitarian disaster or crisis.

The humanitarian sector worldwide is confronted with an increasing demand for humanitarian aid and emergency response services. In the last 10 years the number of people affected by crises has almost doubled and the cost of international humanitarian aid has tripled. The needs and conditions of people affected by these crises have also changed. Over the recent years, there is a growing recognition that, in many cases, traditional humanitarian assistance tools, services and models would
need to better reflect these changing emergency contexts.

These innovations span a wide range, including for instance new technologies such as innovative shelter solutions; smarter use of information, employing mobile technology and big data analysis; to systems changes, for instance related to the channelling of finance to affected areas.

The Coalition will comprise of governmental actors, non-governmental organizations (NGO’s), knowledge institutes, academia, businesses (incl. small and medium sized enterprises (SME’s)) and humanitarian organisations in the Netherlands.
Global

title_narrative: Partners for Resilience Inner Niger Delta region
description_narrative: PfR regional activities in Westerm Africa, along the Inner Delta of the river Niger.  Promote the rational and equitable management of water resources that make vulnerable groups, particularly migrants (fishermen and herders), safe from the risks of natural disasters and the effects of hydro-agricultural development by maintaining the ecosystem services of wetlands in river basins.

The subregion is characterized by recurring natural disasters increasingly linked to climate change, with the consequence of increasing fragility of livelihoods and the vulnerability of communities to these hazards and related environmental challenges. These disasters have increased in frequency and intensity and their impact is increasingly significant in rural communities, especially the most vulnerable, especially those whose livelihoods depend on the primary sector (fishing, agriculture, livestock). Indeed, these recurring climatic risks lead to production deficits, livestock losses and reduced availability of fish and forest stocks.

Capacity development becomes a major focus for securing the livelihoods of vulnerable communities at the 3 targeted countries in the subregion namely Mali, Burkina Faso and Guinea, which share the Niger Basin. 
 Advocacy & Lobbying targeting decision-makers / strategic players based on power mapping

- Establishment and / or strengthening of coalitions at the sub-regional level for citizen control and monitoring by water resource user groups (local organizations, umbrella organizations) for better accountability of decision-makers.

Authorities in Mali, Burkina Faco and Guinee Conakre. 
Fishermen, farmers, women groups
Mali, Burkina Faso and Guinea Conakry

title_narrative: Dutch Surge support for Emergency water, sanitation and hygiene
description_narrative: The Dutch Surge Support (DSS) sends Dutch water and sanitation experts to water-related disasters around the world to contribute to better international response and increased knowledge management in water-related disasters.

A growing number of countries face severe water related issues caused by climate change, enveronmental degradation causing water stress, water scarcity and pollution. This has an impact on drinking water, food supplies, infrastucture and economic development, and on vulnerable ecosystems and the stability of societies. Safe drinking water is one of the most urgent needs in emergency situations and lack of clean water and sanitation leads to disease and child mortality and increase of the workload of vulnerability of women and girls in developing countries. Water scarcity is a potential source of conflict, while floods often cause serious damage and claim many victims.

This project aims to create a Dutch facility for surge support related to water to support humanitian organisations working in water related emergency response by identification and secondment of specialist staff that can be deployed during humanitarian response to crisis. The facility will cover emergency water related fields when appropiate. Besides WASH and water management there will also be a particular focus on thos capacity gaps identified within the United Nations clusters, such as expertise in urban WASH, (complex) sanitation or hydrogeology.
The DSS is an initiative started by the Dutch government, the Netherlands Red Cross, and the Dutch water sector.

The facility shall draw upon expertise available in the Netherlands. It will also contribute to raise interest among Netherlands water sector partners. Experts will be deployed aroud the world in emergency situations.
Tbd

The   PARATUS   project   aims   to   develop a   service   for   multi-hazard   systemic   vulnerability  and  dynamic  risk  scenarios  that  considers  the  uncertainties  of  the  risk  components,  and  supports    the  evaluation  of  adaptation  measures  with  and  for  first  and  second  responders,  and  other  stakeholders.

The Covid-19 pandemic and climate crisis have taught us hard lessons about the systemic impact of compounding disasters. Stakeholders in disaster risk management are faced with the challenge to adapt their risk reduction policies and emergency plans but lack the tools to account for the cross-sectoral impacts and dynamic nature of the risks involved.

Based on a thorough analysis of  the  current  risk situation,  and  ongoing  trends,  scenarios  of  multi-hazard  impacts  are  co-designed  with  stakeholders,  and developed in four case study areas (Alpine transportation corridors, Romanian civil protection, earthquake threats  to  the  megacity  of  Istanbul,  and  impact-based  forecasting  related  to  tropical  cyclone  threats  and other compounding events to preparedness planning in the Caribbean).  The project aims to develop a cloud-based  simulation  and  information  service  building  on  results  from  previous  EU  projects  with guidelines on approaches,  best  practices,  data  sources  and  analysis  tools  for  risk  assessment,  simulation  of  possible  scenarios  and  decision  support  tools  for  the  evaluation  of  optimal  risk  mitigation/adaptation  measures. Through the use of participatory planning tools, and serious games, stakeholder will evaluate the options for risk reduction to support technical policy improvements and implementation of actions,  considering possible scenarios of   changing   hazards, exposure and vulnerability.
Caribbean region, Alps mountain region, Romania,, Turkey/Istanbul.

The objective of this project is to change the 510 development team to a rapid prototyping team with a clear global service offering to the IFRC Network, and to initiate a first set of support projects to national societies. When the service is initiated and national societies are requesting the services, the cost-recovery model of 510 will ensure the sustainability of the initial investment from the IH extra projects fund.

Within the IFRC Network more cash programs are planned and conducted than ever before. The current COVID appeal has already highlighted 22 national societies in the Africa region that will do cash programs for livelihoods. Many of those national societies have limited to no experience with cash programming. They find programmatic cash expertise through online courses and IFRC delegates. There however remains a gap in the IFRC Network on Cash Information Management experts. This gap is critical because the information management component in cash programming is significant. Additionally there is a big gap in training opportunities and standard toolkits for national societies to implement cash information management.

NLRC-510 will develop a Cash IM service and products, which will help national societies to implement cash programs supported by information management systems, digital technology and use data analytics to get good insights and reports. We will create a scale up and future plan for 121. The most feasible route to take with the system is to productize validated key components of it.

NLRC-510 & 121 team
British Red Cross Cash Hub
IFRC Cash IM team
National Societies

title_narrative: Data literacy in the IFRC Network
description_narrative: One of the key activities in the new IFRC Digital Strategy is to close the digital divide in the network, and to build the data literacy of all national societies. Together with the IFRC Intervention team we want to develop a training curriculum that helps national societies to move along the levels of maturity in the IFRC Digital Maturity model (levels 1-5).

The current training package is aimed at national societies in level 1 of the digital maturity (basic). 510 however is frequently requested to provide trainings to people in the national societies who already have good basic data skills, but need to improve their skills to deliver more advance data and digital support to their national society.

Currently a basic data playbook for national societies exists, and an e-learning on data for volunteers. Both have been developed in a collaboration between IFRC, NLRC-510 and American Red Cross. The current training package is however aimed at national societies in level 1 of the digital maturity (basic). Many of these training materials have been produced over the last years. 510 has trained over 20 national societies on various subjects related to data & digital, including strategic trainings on how to establish data teams. However, these materials need to be combined in a good curriculum that matches the maturity levels. Additionally, the content has to be agreed with IFRC, and translated in several languages.

NLRC-510
IFCR Intervention Team
IFCR data literacy team
American Red Cross
Global

The objective of this project is to change the 510 development team to a rapid prototyping team with a clear global service offering to the IFRC Network, and to initiate a first set of support projects to national societies. When the service is initiated and national societies are requesting the services, the cost-recovery model of 510 will ensure the sustainability of the initial investment from the IH extra projects fund.

The IFRC Digital Strategy will bring an increasing amount of data and digital work in the humanitarian programs of national societies. However, embedding digital technology in humanitarian operations is a real challenge.

NLRC-510 can help national societies identify their biggest opportunities to use data and digital (business value case mapping), to use a human centered design approach to collect user insights and use the development team technical knowledge to create a set of requirements for a solution. Based on the requirements our team can develop with the national society a rapid prototype that can be field tested and use on a small scale with aid workers and beneficiaries. With this user tested prototype the national society can work with 510 to implement the solution with one of their local or global IT and digital service providers and start a development or procurement of an operational platform. The handholding during this phase will increase the likelihood of national societies getting value out of their investments in data and digital technology. This service will help national societies to fast track their digital maturity, to prioritize the most valuable investments, and to do research and development properly, before using scarce resources to develop software or data science solutions.

The NLRC-510 development team/rapid prototyping team
IFRC and the Movement
National Societies

title_narrative: Data and Digital Support to NS
description_narrative: Through this project the Netherlands Red Cross supports RCRC NS in developing and integrating data products or digital services in their regular activities and processes.

Data and digital technology are becoming increasingly important and offer great potential for improving the speed, quality and cost effectiveness of humanitarian aid. The IFRC has emphasized this by making "digital transformation" a pillar in their current strategy. NS need to build the requisite capacity to successfully utilise data products and/or digital technology in their regular work. This project assists these NS in this process and makes available to them the skills and competencies of 510, the data initiative of the Netherlands Red Cross, enabling all to accelerate the digital transformation of the beneficiary NS.
Through this project remote technical assistance can be provided and in some instances complementary salary and/or equipment support is also provided.

RCRC NS anywhere in the world.
IFRC
NLRC
This project has global coverage.

title_narrative: Innovating Climate services through Integrating Scientific and local Knowledge
description_narrative:
The NLRC/510 is part of a consortium that implements the overall project. The main objective of the I-CISK project is to develop next-generation CS that follow a social and behaviourally informed approach for co-producing CS that meet the climate information needs of citizens, decision makers and stakeholders at the spatial and temporal scale relevant to them.

NLRC/510 is responsible for the following tasks in this programme:
WP1: Lead the Living Lab in Namibia, supported by the Namibia Red Cross Society. 
WP2: Lead task 2.2 on identifying local knowledge and contribute to the other tasks. 
WP3: contribute to tasks 3.2 up to and including 3.5. 
WP5: contribute to task 5.5 business development bringing in also the perspective of public services versus private sector services. 
WP6: contribute to several dissemination and capacity building activities. 
WP7: Contribute to the evaluation of the impact of the Living Labs.

European and international collaborative research efforts have established a solid scientific foundation for an effective CS value chain. This includes advanced scientific knowledge, monitoring and modelling of climate change and the impacts of climate extremes; and services for the provision of new and relevant climate data through open access data platforms such as Copernicus and GEOSS, citizen science, through open data exchange standards and interoperability (e.g. INSPIRE, OGC). There are, however, several barriers that impede the current generation of CS achieving the full opportunity of their value-proposition. These challenges include the failure to incorporate the social and behavioural factors and the local knowledge and customs of their users. Additional challenges are in; (i) the understanding of the multi-temporal and multi-scalar dimension of climate-related impacts and actions; (ii) the translation of CS-provided data into actionable information; (iii) the consideration of reinforcing or balancing feedback loops associated to users’ decisions based on CS; and (iv) the lack of trans-disciplinary 
approaches across the full CS value chain. There are also challenges in delivering tailor-made and robust services at the scale relevant to users; and an as yet maturing European climate services sector7. The I-CISK project aims to seize these untaken opportunities.

In seven geographically and sectorally diverse living labs (LL), I-CISK showcases its human-centred co-design, co-creation, co-implementation, and co-evaluation approach across key sectors vulnerable to climate change in Europe and beyond. This I-CISK co-production framework builds on the wealth of existing and expanding data and services from Copernicus and GEOSS to provide locally relevant CS. The framework will innovate existing CS frameworks by integrating the local data and knowledge, perceptions and preferences of users with research 
based scientific knowledge. I-CISK will seamlessly link climate and impact and adaptation information at different temporal scales from sub-seasonal to seasonal forecasts to decadal predictions and climate scale projections by including in the decision-making process the effects of adaptation options in a multi-timescale, multi-sector, multi-hazard setting. This human-centred approach realises the full potential of the CS value proposition through bridging the current gap at the downstream end of the CS value chain.
Users of Climate Services

title_narrative: Personal Protection Equipment supplies to the Caribbean during Covid-19
description_narrative: PPE's supply to the Caribbean during Covid-19
Regional support to the entire NAP program in the Caribbean including regional activities.
The NAP program takes place on six islands in the Caribbean and requires a regional support structure.
Posting a regional program manager on one of the Caribbean islands supported by a PO and PA ad HQ.
The six overseas branches
Caribbean region

title_narrative: Syria crisis - support to residents and displaced persons
description_narrative: Syria is suffering since 2011 from a (protracted) crisis and residents and displaced populations in conflict and or besieged areas are hard to reach with medical aid and supplies

title_narrative: Preparing for disasters in the Philippines: training communities and local government
description_narrative: The programme aims to contribute to a common local development agenda for building disaster resilient communities in the Philippines. It hopes to improve the responsiveness and transparency of Local Government Units (LGU) by ensuring participatory and transparent processes for disaster risk reduction and development.

title_narrative: Hurricane Matthew 2016: Aruba RC support to Haiti
description_narrative: Directly after Hurricane Matthew hit Haiti an early response came from the Aruba Red Cross. Aruba Red Cross sent two trained volunteers with emergency supplies to Haiti.

Hurricane Matthew, the strongest storm of the 2016 Atlantic Hurricane season, crossed Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Cuba and The Bahamas. It hit Haiti on October 4th 2016. An early response was undertaken from Aruba because of its relatively close situated.
Logistics to transport volunteers and supplies were offered by Dutch Marine. Tarps, tents, medical supplies and bottled water were transported to Haiti.
Those affected by Hurricane Matthew
Haiti

The objective of this operation is to ensure that people affected by Hurricane Matthew in the Sud, Grand’Anse, Nippes, Sud-Est, Ouest and Nord-Ouest departments receive appropriate assistance in a timely, effective, and efficient manner; and that they are provided with the necessary support in order to recover with increased disaster resilience.

The programme assists areas with high potential impact of El Nino with possible flood occurrences leading to loss of lives; displacement of population; destruction of properties and infrastructure; and interrupt access to basic social services such as schools, health facilities and markets. Additionally, these areas are also likely to experience outbreak of secondary hazards associated with flooding such as water and vector borne diseases.

This project makes funds available to send delegates to meet the humanitarian assistance needs of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Delegate are often university-educated trainers, advisors, management- and/or information specialists able to analyse complex situations and make sound recommendations on how to proceed, whilst reconciling the needs of victims with increasingly complex donor requirements.
Within this programme NLRC supports IFRC and ICRC with delegates, but also works bilaterally by teaming up with a Partner NS without mediation by the ICRC or IFRC.
Specialists on Shelter, Health, WASH, Food, Contingency and Mitigation
Delegates are assigned in Afghanistan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Kenya, Lebanon, Malawi, Palestine, South Sudan, Sudan and Tanzania.

Within this programme NLRC supports IFRC and ICRC with delegates, but also works bilaterally by teaming up with a Partner NS without mediation by the ICRC or IFRC.

title_narrative: 3FM Serious Request 2015: The Next Generation, technical assistance
description_narrative: The programme This Next Generation, Supporting the development of young people in war and conflict. The theme focusses on children and young adults who live in the most extreme circumstances and therefore have little chance on schooling and development. They are the silent victims of war. The funding of this programme is made possible by 3FM fundraising activity.
The aim of the programme is to make young people who have to cope with conflict and that are part of ‘this next generation’ more resilient to the consequences of conflict.

The Red Cross supports the development of young people in war and conflict by focussing on four different area's: education and personal development, psychosocial support, food and income for families, and emergency assistance.
This project contains the technical support and advisors for implementing the programme.
Technical support is offered from NLRC HQ in The Hague.

title_narrative: 3FM Serious Request 2015: The Next Generation, evaluation, learning
description_narrative: The programme This Next Generation, Supporting the development of young people in war and conflict. The theme focusses on children and young adults who live in the most extreme circumstances and therefore have little chance on schooling and development. They are the silent victims of war. The funding of this programme is made possible by 3FM fundraising activity.
The aim of the programme is to make young people who have to cope with conflict and that are part of ‘this next generation’ more resilient to the consequences of conflict.

The Red Cross supports the development of young people in war and conflict by focussing on four different area's: education and personal development, psychosocial support, food and income for families, and emergency assistance.
This project contains the general costs of HQ for implementing the programme.
NLRC HQ, The Hague.

title_narrative: Addressing vulnerabilities of refugees and host communities in Lebanon affected by the Syria Crisis
description_narrative: This programme will provide a coherent and coordinated response to the crisis following the Syria conflict. The Madad-funded initiative is implemented in multiple contexts with various institutional challenges and varying needs of vulnerable persons from Syria as well as in the host communities, as is also evident in the Response Plans of Lebanon and Jordan and the 3RP country chapters of Turkey, Egypt and Iraq.

title_narrative: Case Study Syrian Refugees in Lebanon
description_narrative: Case study on support for Syrian refugees in Lebanon.

title_narrative: HIV prevention and support of vulnerable groups: Technical support to the six different Red Cross and Red Crescent societies
description_narrative: The overall goal is HIV prevention and provide support to vulnerable groups affected by HIV and Aids. This specific sub activity provides technical support to the six different Red Cross and Red Crescent societies

title_narrative: HIV prevention and support of vulnerable groups: execution of the evaluation through collective evaluation of NL MFS facility
description_narrative: The overall goal is HIV prevention and provide support to vulnerable groups affected by HIV and Aids. This specific sub activity consists of the evaluation through collective evaluation of NL MFS facility

title_narrative: HIV prevention and support of vulnerable groups: execution of midterm review to develop and implement learnings within the programme implemented by six national Red Cross and Red Crescent societies
description_narrative: The overall goal is HIV prevention and provide support to vulnerable groups affected by HIV and Aids. This specific sub activity consists of the execution of a midterm review to develop and implement learnings within the programme implemented by six national Red Cross and Red Crescent societies
Midterm review to extract lessons learned from the specific projects and activities within the MSF II program.

title_narrative: 3FM Serious Request 2010: HIV prevention & treatment General cost OVC
description_narrative: The programme aims to reduce the impact of HIV in a number of countries with high prevalence rates. The programme combines prevention, care and support activities with special attention for orphans and vulnerable children (OVC). Activities that are being organized include among others peer education, home visits and test sessions. Furthermore, OVC are enabled to go to school and receive psychosocial support.

EI Nino caused serious drought in Ethiopia, which brought more than 10 million people dependable of emergency food support. Of this population 1,2 million reside in the Tigray region. Especially children and lactating mothers are physically weak and underweight, making them more vulnerable.
In this project costs of NLRC Headquarter are booked.
This programme supports investment in Workplace First Aid businesses as part of a Financial Sustainability objective
